newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian gilt, t-bills yields fall, call steady.
newsitem.headline: Indian gilt, t-bills yields fall, call steady.

text.p: Yields on government securities fell on Saturday in inter-bank trade after the central bank's weekly treasury bill auction on Friday drew more bidders, dealers said.
"There has been drastic drop in yields on short-dated securities," said Vinod Dixit, a dealer at Centurion Bank. "The yields are down by nearly 75 basis points."

Yields on the 13.50 percent 1997 stock fell to 9.95 percent from 10.76 percent on Friday. The yields on 13.50 percent 1998 stock dropped to 11.14 percent against 11.67 percent and on 13.62 percent 1998 stock it slipped to 11.65 percent from 11.78 percent, dealers said.
Yields on treasury bills maturing in October 1997 eased to 9.75 percent from 10 percent, and for January 1997 maturity treasury bill it slumped to 6.60 percent from 7.35 percent.
Dealers said the falling yields reflected easy money conditions with call rates at 1.75-2.0 percent after the central bank pumped liquidity into the system.

The latest weekly treasury bill auction on Friday for a notified amount of 5.0 billion rupees attracted bids for 20 billion rupees which drove down the yield to 6.94 percent from 8.86 percent a week ago.
Dealers said the newly auctioned 91-day treasury bill was traded at an yield of 6.63 percent yield.
Call money rates closed steady at 1.75-2.00 on Saturday.
There were no trades in commercial paper and certificates of deposit and the inter-corporate deposits were quoted at 18-19.5 percent for P1+ rated companies.
